Welcome! On behalf of the Board of Directors and membership of the Manatee Chamber of Commerce, I share a warm welcome to the greater Manatee County region. This community guide and business directory is a valuable tool in learning more about our area and connecting with local businesses, non-profits, and partner agencies. Whether you are a lifelong resident, newcomer, or visitor to our slice of paradise, the Manatee Chamber is here to help you. With 2,000+ members, we can offer important referrals to friendly, community-focused business people whose products and services meet your needs. For more than 130 years, the Chamber has focused on strengthening local businesses and enhancing the quality of life that makes the greater Manatee County area an ideal place to live, work, play, and own a business. The ”secret is out” and our region continues to grow. There is something for everyone – young professionals looking to grow their careers, families searching for a community to put down roots, retirees starting their next chapter, and visitors wanting a destination that reflects authentic Florida amenities. We pride ourselves on our “friendly people and business-friendly” mindset. From Lakewood Ranch to Anna Maria Island, Parrish to Palmetto, Ellenton to Bradenton – and lots of great areas beyond and between – you’ll find that our fantastic quality of life has the warm personality of a small town with the amenities and innovation of a major metro region. With crystal clear beaches, active greenspaces, and quiet, pristine preserves, Manatee County is home to incredible natural resources. Layered in are vibrant business districts, cultural gems, and unique neighborhoods offering plenty of variety. I personally invite you to use the Manatee Chamber to make connections and get involved. We hope that you will give us a call, stop by our offices, or connect with us online… it’s your Chamber – use it! Residential Telephone, Television, Internet Spectrum by Charter Communications 	(941) 748-3816 Frontier Communications	(800) 921‑8101 Comcast Cable 	(800) 934-6489 planning future MANATEE COUNTY IS GROWING FAST BUT PRESERVING IT’S FRIENDLY SMALL-TOWN APPEAL Nestled along the shores of Florida’s Gulf Coast between St. Petersburg and Sarasota lies a haven for those seeking relaxation and adventure alike. From the pristine turquoise waters and sugar-white sand beaches of Anna Maria Island to the bustling city landscape of Bradenton, to the award-winning master design of Lakewood Ranch, it’s easy to see why Manatee County is one of the fastest-growing counties in Florida. What once was a quiet retirement community whose population swelled with snowbirds during the fall and winter months is now home to nearly 415,000 permanent residents and welcomes roughly 1 million visitors each year. Its ample sunshine, tranquil gulf breezes and “Old Florida” ambiance make Manatee County a delightful place to live, work, play, and own a business. “I think the Bradenton area is unique because it’s managed to maintain its character and small-town appeal despite a huge influx of residents in recent years,” said Nicholas Azzara, communications manager for the Bradenton Area Convention and Visitors Bureau. “There’s growth everywhere you look, but leaders have done a great job of managing development in order to preserve the charm our community has always had.” Composed of distinct yet cohesive communities including Anna Maria, Bradenton, Bradenton Beach, Cortez, Ellenton, Holmes Beach, Lakewood Ranch, Longboat Key, Myakka City, Palmetto, and Parrish, every area of Manatee County is home to friendly people who are working to grow the business community while maintaining a quality of life that has garnered the region so much attention. And to say the area has experienced growth is an understatement. According to the U.S. Census Bureau, the county grew 27.6 percent from 2010 to 2021. By comparison, the U.S. population grew 7.3 percent and Florida’s population grew 15.6 percent during that same period. The northern portion of the county, in particular, is attracting significant investment. But unlike areas that gave way to expansive resorts and amusement parks, visitors and residents of Manatee County enjoy bustling downtowns offering entertainment, dining, history, culture and more. Significant areas of growth include master-planned developments, mixed-use amenities and diverse housing options. Those seeking to embrace Florida at its most natural can enjoy fascinating tours of working wineries, dairy and produce farms, as well as thousands of acres of public greenspace and parks. The area’s largest city is Bradenton, whose location on the Manatee River has attracted more than 60,000 residents. Though the Bradenton area is known for its beaches, downtown Bradenton has developed into a historical and thriving area that includes a Main Street, Riverwalk, boutiques, craft breweries and sidewalk cafes. People are attracted to the area by a combination of quality of life and a diversified palette of art, baseball, incredible weather, beautiful parks and preserves, vibrant downtown entertainment, white sandy beaches and a multitude of job opportunities and housing options according to Bradenton Mayor Mayor Gene Brown. While the city’s 14.4-square-miles are landlocked, the city is focused on “smart growth,” specifically in the downtown area. “For me, smart growth is ‘urban core development.’ We want to bring more businesses downtown and get people moving back downtown. We want to grow our core area and offer all the amenities that make it a great place to live, work and play,” Brown said. “The whole goal is to keep people from ever having to get in their car to go anywhere else.” The area’s second-largest city, Palmetto, offers a mix of small-town charm with modern-day appeal. Its close proximity to major roadways like U.S. 41, I-75, I-275 and the Sunshine Skyway Bridge has been a business attractor. “I hear from so many people who relocate to Palmetto that it is a great place to live with the reason so often given that it still has a ‘small town feel,’” said Palmetto Mayor Shirley Bryant. “There have been many changes over the last few years aimed at the overall quality of life – specifically redevelopment with several projects still in the works – but always with an eye on retaining the warmth of our community.” Recent and ongoing projects include an enhancement to the Bradenton Area Convention Center that connects it with the new 255-room Marriott Hotel currently under construction next door, the recently completed Connor Park, and the nearly completed 20,000-square-foot police department. Another popular area of Manatee County is Lakewood Ranch, a thriving community of more than 20,000 homes that run the gamut from apartments to multi-million-dollar luxury estates. The nationally award-winning master planned community is home to more than 63,000 residents, and at more than 50 square miles, feels like its own city. With 16 vibrant and varied business districts – including three town centers – Lakewood Ranch has all the shopping, dining, entertainment, schools, healthcare, nature and recreational options you could want. At the heart of Lakewood Ranch is Main Street, a picturesque town center lined with cafes and boutiques, specialty shops, international restaurants and cinemas. The open-air, pedestrian-friendly area provides a unique place for strolling and shopping and is home to dozens of community events, concerts and festivals throughout the year. Besides the more well-known cities and beaches, Manatee County has some off-the-beaten-path places to visit as well, including the Cortez Historic Fishing Village. Home to the Florida Maritime Museum, Cortez is the oldest working fishing village in Florida and offers guests activities like quilting, soap-making, wood crafting, net mending and fish fileting. Award-winning arts, and historical and cultural amenities add to a rich ecosystem that provides enriching educational and entertainment options for all ages. “I like to describe the Manatee County region as having all the amenities and economic drivers of a major metro with the friendly, approachable feel of your favorite neighborhood,” said Jacki Dezelski, President and CEO of the Manatee Chamber of Commerce. “I have lived here for more than 40 years and the progress and evolution that has taken place is so exciting.” s DISTINCTIVE COMMUNITIES VIBRANT COMMUNITIES Manatee County is a Jewel on the Suncoast W ith a rich history dating back centuries, Manatee County is built on the legacy left by individuals who thrived living along the Manatee River and the Gulf of Mexico. As the county’s population continues to grow and expand its footprint, there are still many opportunities to explore nature and landmarks that speak to the county’s rich culture. De Soto National Memorial Park sits on the Manatee River and honors Hernando de Soto, who in 1539 arrived at the mouth of Tampa Bay with his men in pursuit of gold. The quest failed, and de Soto moved north to Georgia, Alabama and Arkansas. Three hundred years later, settlers were offered land in the area free of charge under the condition that they stay for a minimum of five years. One of the settlers was Josiah Gates, who lived in what was then the Village of Manatee – present-day East Bradenton. The legacy is remembered at the Manatee Village Historical Park, only a few miles from present-day downtown Bradenton. In the 1840s, Hector and Joseph Braden settled in the area that bears their name. The ruins of Braden Castle remain protected to this day. Robert Gamble settled in what is now Ellenton, and his memory is preserved at Gamble Plantation Historic State Park. In 1855 – the year Manatee County was officially established – the area was booming with citrus growers, cattle ranchers and farmers. With the turn of the 20th century, Manatee County enjoyed major inventions and the Manatee River propelled the area’s agricultural sector. The annual De Soto Heritage Festival has honored the area’s rich history for nearly 80 years, commemorating the past while looking to the future. The festival receives regional and national recognition. For a look at Florida’s natural history, head east of Interstate 75 to Myakka River State Park. There’s no end to the wildlife native to the area, including alligators thriving in their natural habitat. Both residents and visitors alike enjoy frequenting the historical parks, landmarks and museums, which are full of Manatee County’s vibrant past and culture. Anna Maria The City of Anna Maria sits at the northern end of Anna Maria Island. The entire city is a bird sanctuary making it ideal for bird watching. This island boasts sandy beaches, crystal clear waters, and many attractions, including museums, shops, and local eateries. Bradenton Bradenton, known as “The Friendly City”, is the largest city in Manatee County with the nationally recognized Riverwalk, Spring Training for Major League Baseball’s Pittsburgh Pirates, the Bradenton Mauraders, cultural attractions and a thriving downtown business district. Bradenton Beach Situated at the southern tip of Anna Maria Island, Bradenton Beach is perfect for individuals who enjoy fishing, fresh seafood, and beautiful vistas. This cozy town has miles of sugar sand beaches and the popular Bridge Street shopping district. Cortez This historic fishing village is chock full of history, culture and fresh-caught cuisine, perfectly located for boating, kayaking, jet skiing, and many other outdoor pursuits. The area is also known for its commercial fishing festival and maritime museum. Ellenton Ellenton is the region’s outlet shopping destination. With its proximity to the Manatee River, Ellenton offers a high quality of life, major transportation connections, and growing development. Holmes Beach With three miles of pristine shoreline in 1.91 square miles, Holmes Beach is a popular tourist destination. This small island community offers wildlife, beaches, boating access, shopping, dining, and more. Lakewood Ranch Spanning more than 31,000 acres, this rapidly growing community is nationally recognized for its award-winning master planning. Lakewood Ranch is focused on active, connected communities and boasts many housing options, attractions, golf courses, business clusters, and outdoor activities. Longboat Key Longboat Key is a barrier island with a foot in both Manatee and Sarasota counties. The town boasts golf courses, numerous restaurants, unique boutiques, and breathtaking Gulf Coast views including Beer Can Island and Whitney Beach. Myakka City Located in southeastern Manatee County, Myakka City combines ranching and agriculture with parks and lakes. Many residents have deep-rooted family ties to the area. Be sure to visit the Crowley Museum and Nature Center. Palmetto Palmetto is one of the largest cities in Manatee County. It is a hub for history, with more than 200 buildings on the National Register of Historic Places. Enjoy a stroll down lush walkways and parks, as well as the Native American Madira Bickel Mound State Archaeological Site for hours of exploration. Parrish Parrish is the county’s fastest growing area north of the Manatee River. The Florida Railroad Museum, which features a six-mile ride through some of Manatee County’s original stomping grounds, is a must-see attraction. The area’s natural beauty enhances flourishing residential areas and a growing business sector. s A+ Education Schools Preparing Students For a Lifetime of Success The School District of Manatee County is one of the 100 largest school districts in the nation with more than 52,000 students. The district is also Manatee County’s largest employer with more than 6,000 employees. The district is made up of 50 traditional public schools, 14 charter schools and one of the most highly-regarded adult and career educational institutions in the nation – Manatee Technical College. As stated in its strategic plan, the district’s vision is to be “an exemplary student-focused school system that develops lifelong learners to be globally competitive.” One of the primary ways the district pursues this vision is by offering unique and exciting academic programs and extracurricular activities that help students prepare for the jobs of tomorrow. It’s called: Education with Innovation and Imagination! Like teaming with Apple Inc., co-founder Steve Wozniak to make Palm View K-8 the first WOZ Ed Pathway school in Florida, and one of the very first in the nation. WOZ Ed schools offer elementary students opportunities to receive instruction in areas like coding, engineering, drones, cyber-security and mobile development. Or placing such a strong emphasis on STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts and math) and career and technical education initiatives that Manatee County students regularly dominate state and national academic and technology-oriented competitions. In 2019, the Manatee District launched the Tampa Bay area’s first Community Partnership School at Manatee Elementary. Community Partnership Schools bringing together four long-term partners (a school district, a nonprofit organization, a college or university and a healthcare provider) to enhance the overall quality of life for not only students at a specific school, but for the surrounding community. The concept has been so successful, the district launched its second Community Partnership School at Daughtrey Elementary in 2022. Also in 2022, the district opened the world’s first Guy Harvey Academy of Arts & Science at Anna Maria Elementary School. The academy was started in collaboration with world-renowned marine wildlife artist and conservationist Dr. Guy Harvey and the curriculum was created in cooperation with the Guy Harvey Foundation. The academy aims to use an art, math and science-based curriculum to educate and engage young students on the importance of preserving oceans and marine life while learning about the world’s environment. The County’s first Dual Language program was introduced at Daughtrey in 2019. Dual Language programs are now at 4 additional elementary schools (Rogers Garden-Bullock, Braden River, Palmetto and Myakka City elementary schools. A sixth program will start at Prine Elementary in August. The School District of Manatee County is financially sound, and thanks to the community’s renewal of a $1 million referendum in 2021, starting teachers in Manatee County are among the highest paid in the state. All Manatee District teachers have received pay increases each of the last five years. To learn more about our school district, visit our website at manateeschools.net . Also, check out the district’s “Good News” page at manateeschools.net/goodnews for information about students, employees and schools. No matter the subject or academic aspiration, there’s a perfect program to fit your career goals. Everglades University Individuals looking for a small-class size should consider Everglades University. Programs such as alternative and renewable energy management, crisis, and disaster management, as well as aviation technology and business administration, are only a few of the options available to students working toward a bachelor’s or master’s degree. It features many services, including audiology and speech, dental care and oral surgery, laboratory and pathology, mental health care, optometry, pharmacy, primary care, radiology, imaging, social work, and women veteran care. va.gov/bay-pines-health-care Information in this article was provided by Centerstone, Florida Department of Health in Manatee County, HCA Florida Blake Hospital, Manatee Healthcare System, Lakewood Ranch Medical Center, Manatee Memorial Hospital, MCR Health, Suncoast Behavioral Health Center and VA Bay Pines Health Care Center . s Full speed ahead From Beachfront to Ball Fields, Opportunities Abound for Visitors, Residents and Businesses Alike Known for its pristine beaches, warm weather, friendly charm – and yes, manatees – it’s easy to see why tourism is one of Manatee County’s top economic drivers. The area welcomes around 1 million visitors each year, bringing more than a $1.3 billion economic impact to the region. Even after the COVID-19 pandemic when other tourist destinations in the country struggled to recover, Manatee County thrived. To accommodate the growing tourism industry, major renovations, construction and improvement plans are underway throughout the county. One of the largest projects is the nearly $50 million renovation and expansion of the Bradenton Area Convention Center in Palmetto, which will add a multipurpose ballroom that could accommodate 900 guests, along with other improvements. The center will connect to a new 252-room Marriott Hotel opening next door in early 2024. Elliott Falcione, director of the Bradenton Area Convention and Visitors Bureau, said the enhancements to the convention center will allow more meeting space for business conferences and events, giving Manatee County the most diverse tourism assets in the entire state of Florida. “We’ll be running on all cylinders,” he said. One of those cylinders is sports tourism, and it’s a huge one for Manatee County. The area is not just the Gulf shores of Anna Maria Island, Holmes Beach and Bradenton Beach – visitors across the world flock to the area for its sports facilities and events. The area’s connection with Major League Baseball’s Pittsburgh Pirates – and its more than 50-year partnership as the team’s spring training location – is another key tourism driver and adds the visibility and investment that comes with professional-level sports franchises. Bradenton also hosts the minor league Bradenton Marauders, as well as year-round training at Pirate City. The Marauders welcome many of the game’s future stars before they gain worldwide acclaim. IMG Academy is another big lure. As one of the world’s most prestigious sports, performance and educational institutions, the 600-acre campus annually attracts hundreds of teams, groups and events for training and competition. The Academy’s boarding school is home to more than 1,200 student athletes hailing from the U.S. and more than 60 other countries across the globe. In East Manatee County, Premier Sports Campus features nearly 150 acres of Celebration-Bermuda grass fields, including 22 FIFA-regulation size fields that host everything from community-level competitions to national and international events. Fields can host soccer, football, lacrosse, rugby, Australian-rules football, field hockey, ultimate frisbee, spike ball and more. Owned by the county, the sports complex includes a 3,000-plus seat stadium with scoreboards and a press box. The complex is currently undergoing several enhancements, including additional restrooms and a 6,500-square-foot permanent tent with air conditioning and enough space to seat 400. Set in the heart of Lakewood Ranch, the Sarasota Polo Club is another popular venue, not just for polo but other social events like concerts and festivals. The immaculate grounds include 45 private equestrian estates, seven Bermuda grass polo fields, a regulation-size polo arena, a half-mile all-weather exercise track, dedicated stick and ball fields, riding trails, on-site stabling for up to 300 horses, on-site veterinarian care and a midfield polo pavilion. Beyond the county’s vibrant tourism market, the region is a profitable place to do business for a wide variety of industries, with diverse, thriving sectors including health care, finance and banking, business services, construction and development, hospitality, logistics/distribution, sports performance, advanced manufacturing, life sciences, real estate, education, and agriculture. Companies with national and international visibility include Tropicana Products, Beall’s Inc., Feld Entertainment, Safran Electrical & Power, Air Products and Chemicals, among others. For more than half a century, SeaPort Manatee has served as one of Florida’s largest and fastest-growing ports, as well as the closest U.S. deep-water seaport to the Panama Canal. Since its inception, this Florida Gulf Coast trade gateway has served as one of the county’s leading economic engines, serving container, bulk, breakbulk, heavy lift, project and general cargo clients. The self-sustaining port generates more than $3.9 billion in annual economic impacts while providing for more than 27,000 direct and indirect jobs – all without benefit of local property tax support. Organizations like the Manatee Chamber of Commerce have placed an emphasis on growing resources for young professionals and entrepreneurs while helping existing businesses expand. The favorable business tax environment, growth rates, educational attainment and young adult affluence are some of the reasons the area is considered a good location for business entrepreneurs. From start-up ventures to family-owned shops to corporate headquarters to major distribution centers – and every type of business in between – the opportunities are endless in Manatee County. s Getting Around Non-Stop Flights and Free Public Transit Hightlight Transportation Options Situated ideally on the breathtaking Gulf Coast, Manatee County is a breeze to get into and around. The county’s transportation infrastructure includes the Manatee County Area Transit, the Sarasota Bradenton International Airport and numerous pedestrian and bicycle amenities. In addition, a new water taxi service could begin ferrying riders between downtown Bradenton and Anna Maria Island beaches as early as summer 2023. Thanks to its close proximity to Interstate 75, Manatee County is within driving distance to other popular Florida destinations – just one hour from Tampa, less than two hours from Orlando and about 3.5 hours from Miami. SARASOTA BRADENTON INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT (SRQ) If you prefer to fly, the Sarasota Bradenton International Airport (SRQ) offers non-stop service on Delta, JetBlue, United, Southwest, American, Breeze, Avelo, Frontier, Allegiant, Sun Country, Air Canada and Elite Airways. The airport is growing just as rapidly as the area it serves and is undergoing a new $73 million five-gate terminal expansion to accommodate the growth. The new terminal will include a four-lane security checkpoint and five boarding hold rooms with 970 seats, as well as restaurants, cafes and a bar. “The continuation of record-breaking numbers demonstrates the need for expansion and represents a major shift in how SRQ is transforming to serve the needs of our fast-growing community,” said Rick Piccolo, President and CEO of SRQ. He said even with the rapid growth, expansions and improvements, the airport prides itself on maintaining a “boutique-type experience” for travelers. MANATEE COUNTY AREA TRANSIT (MCAT) From Parrish to Longboat Key, Myakka to Anna Maria – and everywhere in between – the award-winning public transportation service helps travelers have a smooth ride. And the best news is, it’s free! Fare Free services began in November 2022 and will continue through early 2024. It includes all MCAT routes. Other amenities include free trolley services offered on Anna Maria Island and Longboat Key, and a beach express available on Sundays and holidays. By visiting mymanatee.org/mcat , residents and visitors can plan a trip, see real-time location of buses, find specific route information and buy bus passes using MCAT throughout the county’s 741-square-mile drivable area. WATER TAXI A water taxi service connecting Bradenton to Anna Maria Island is in the final stages of approval to include two 49-passenger vessels named “Downtown Duchess” and “Miss Anna Maria.” The boats will ferry customers from the day dock along the Bradenton Riverwalk to the Anna Maria Island Pier, the Bradenton Beach Pier, one of the boat ramps near Coquina Beach and then back again. Eventually, Palmetto will be connected to the service, with a third vessel that could connect the Ellenton area near the U.S. 301 – I-75 intersection and Fort Hamer Park. s THINGS TO SEE & DO Amazing Entertainment Come Explore Endless Adventures Many visitors and residents are attracted to the area because of the miles of beautiful beaches and outstanding weather. Strates named Manatee County Fair midway provider – Amusement Today Skip to content Subscribe Digital Issue Articles Digital Issue Media Kit About Video Track Golden Ticket Awards Contact Articles Digital Issue Media Kit About Video Track Golden Ticket Awards Contact Articles Digital Issue Media Kit About Video Track Golden Ticket Awards Contact Articles Digital Issue Media Kit About Video Track Golden Ticket Awards Contact Strates named Manatee County Fair midway provider January 3, 2025 9:48 am PALMETTO, Fla. — The James E. Strates Shows, one of North America’s leading outdoor amusement providers, has proudly signed an agreement with the Manatee River Fair Association, Inc.to serve as the exclusive carnival midway provider for the annual Manatee County Fair in Palmetto, Florida. “Being part of the Manatee County Fair is an honor as the Fair celebrates and highlights the community’s rich agricultural traditions, diverse talents, and cultural heritage,” said John Strates, third-generation carnival owner and Director of Operations. “Strates Shows is dedicated to providing a safe and exciting carnival midway experience, where families can relax, have fun, and create treasured memories to last a lifetime.” “We look forward to partnering with the Strates Shows in providing a new midway experience for our guests, said Danny Alfonso, Manatee County Fair CEO-Fair Manager. “The Strates family are highly respected in our industry, not only for their deep generational history, but more importantly for their excellence in professionalism as they truly partner with each fair, to provide a unique, safe and exciting experience for their guests.” For over a century, James E. Strates Shows has been a trusted name in the world of carnival midways, bringing world-class entertainment to fairs and festivals across the Eastern Seaboard. With a legacy of excellence, Strates Shows sets itself apart through a carefully curated blend of traditional charm and modern thrill. Strates Shows is known for its state-of-the-art rides, where cutting-edge technology meets breathtaking excitement. From exhilarating roller coasters and towering Ferris wheels to family- friendly classics, Strates Shows offers a wide range of attractions designed to create unforgettable moments for all ages. The company’s commitment to innovation keeps the experience fresh and exciting, while safety remains a top priority. “With a history of providing high-quality, family-friendly entertainment, James E. Strates Shows continues to set the standard for carnival midways across North America,” said Strates Shows Press Agent Marty Biniasz. “Whether you’re a thrill-seeker, a food lover, or simply looking for a day of family fun, Strates Shows offers a timeless experience that keeps fairgoers coming back year after year.” Strates Shows, a proud family-owned and operated business, is led by the third generation of the Strates family, including Jimmy, Jay, John, and Susan. Continuing the legacy, Nick Strates joined the show full-time in 2015 as part of the fourth generation, ensuring the tradition lives on. The carnival midway at the Manatee County Fair will feature a collection of state-of-the-art carnival rides, games, and concessions. The lineup includes a dedicated Kiddieland for young children, along with midway favorites such as the “Claw,” “Dream Wheel,” and “Sky Flyer.” The Manatee County Fair is considered the largest annual event in the Bradenton-Sarasota area. The 109 th edition of the Fair is scheduled to take place January 16 through January 26, 2025 at the Fairgrounds in Palmetto. For Fair information visit www.manateecountyfair.com. “We are delighted to have Strates Shows join with us as we present “Keeping Agriculture Alive in 2025” at the Manatee County Fairgrounds, adds Alfonso. Amick CAP®, CFRE Chief Cheerleader & CEO Florida Cultural Group, Inc. Janene M. Amick’s impressive background paints a picture of a dynamic and dedicated leader, deeply committed to both her community and the arts. As the CEO of the Florid Cultural Group and its Manatee Performing Arts Center (MPAC) campus, her entrepreneurial spirit is evident, as she has successfully guided the organization for nearly two decades. Her leadership philosophy, “Lead with your Strengths,” suggests a focus on empowerment, collaboration, and the cultivation of individual and collective talents. Having joined the company formally known as Manatee Players, Inc. in 2005, Janene’s tenure speaks to both her loyalty to the organization and her strategic vision for its growth. Her cross-sector experience spans the arts, marketing, corporate entrepreneurship, and nonprofit management, which enables her to bring a comprehensive and innovative approach to her role. Janene is highly recognized in her community, where she has earned numerous accolades for her leadership and volunteerism, including the prestigious Ed Hunzeker Hospitality Leadership Award (2019) and the Lifetime Achievement Award for community volunteer service in 2017. She has also been recognized as one of BIZ (941) 2012’s People to Watch, underscoring her influence and role as a change-maker in the region. In addition to her work at MPAC, Janene has served in various leadership capacities, including as Past President of the Bradenton Kiwanis Club, a board member of the MCR Health Board of Directors, and an appointed Commissioner of the Bradenton Housing Authority. Her extensive involvement with organizations like the VFW Women’s Auxiliary, the American Fundraising Professionals (AFP), and the Bradenton Area Cultural Advisory Committee further reflects her commitment to strengthening the local nonprofit and cultural sectors. Her educational achievements are equally impressive, with certifications in nonprofit management, philanthropy, and fundraising. Janene’s designation as a Certified Fund-Raising Executive (CFRE) and Chartered Advisor in Philanthropy (CAP) positions her as an expert in nonprofit management and strategic fundraising. Her Executive Education Certificate in Nonprofit Management from Harvard University further underscores her commitment to continual learning and professional growth. At the heart of Janene’s work is a passion for nonprofit collaborations and partnerships. She thrives on providing others with opportunities to shine and fostering a sense of community impact through shared experiences and initiatives. Through her leadership, Janene Amick continues to play a pivotal role in the cultural, philanthropic, and social landscape of Bradenton and beyond. Her focus on community-building and her relentless dedication to the arts have left a lasting impression on the region. Show more Show less EMAIL Rick Kerby Producing Artistic Director Rick Kerby is a distinguished figure in the performing arts, renowned for his extensive career as both a performer and director. As the Producing Artistic Director of the Manatee Players, he has been instrumental in shaping the theater’s artistic vision for over two decades, earning accolades such as the “Master Director” title from Sarasota Magazine in 2013 and multiple Handy Awards. Before his tenure in Bradenton, Rick’s performance career spanned over thirty countries and all fifty U.S. states. He graced Broadway stages and national tours, including productions like A Match Made in Heaven and Yankee Doodle Dandy. His international tours featured roles in Seven Brides for Seven Brothers, The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas, and Oklahoma!, where he also served as dance captain. Beyond theater, Rick performed aboard major cruise lines such as Royal Viking, Holland America, and Norwegian, and appeared in Las Vegas venues like the Aladdin Hotel and Bally’s Casino. In his role as Entertainment Director for the USO of Metropolitan New York, Rick organized the Miss USO Contest and led a troupe that performed internationally, with appearances on The Today Show, Good Morning America, Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade, and The Miss America Pageant. Rick’s commitment to education is evident through his teaching positions at institutions like Wagner College and The Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts in New York City. He has also held leadership roles at the Florida Theatre Conference, the Florida Association of Community Theaters, and the American Association of Community Theatres, where he is a past president. As a published author, Rick co-authored “Dream: Tales from the Pikes Peak Writers,” a collection of short stories. He also authored “Improv with Older Actors,” a guidebook accompanied by a flash card set designed to facilitate improvisational activities for senior performers. Rick Kerby’s multifaceted career underscores his unwavering dedication to the performing arts, significantly influencing both regional and national theater communities. Show more Show less EMAIL Jeff Evans Comptroller The Comptroller is responsible for preparing financial statements, processing deposits, and payments, maintaining cash controls, managing the payroll and human resources administration, audit preparation, and maintaining all financial accounts. The Comptroller is responsible for preparing financial statements, processing deposits, and payments, maintaining cash controls, managing the payroll and human resources administration, audit preparation, and maintaining all financial accounts. Jeff is retired from a 45-year career in the financial services industry which encompassed senior and executive management roles in banking, brokerage, and mutual fund servicing. Jeff, his wife, Nitza, and daughter, Alina, moved to Florida from New Jersey in 2005. When Alina first appeared in one of our shows in 2009, Jeff got involved as a tech volunteer. He has since been a Board member and served as our Treasurer and Board Chair. He has been the Comptroller since 2017. Show more Show less EMAIL Kristin Ribble Production Manager The Production Manager is responsible for coordinating the rehearsal schedules, technical needs and budget of all in-house produced productions. The Production Manager acts as the liaison among the production team and between the production team, including Guest Directors, and the Producing Artistic Director. Kristin started her current position as the Production Manager for Manatee Players in July of 2008, celebrating her 10 year anniversary this year! She has been involved, either onstage or behind the scenes, in over 130 productions since the age of 12, and she has Stage Managed over 60 productions here at MPAC! Most recently she served as Stage Manager for our productions of HUNCHBACK OF NOTRE DAME, A LITTLE NIGHT MUSIC, THE PRODUCERS, BOYNTON BEACH CLUB, LITTLE SHOP, ASSASSINS, and 42nd STREET! Some of her favorite stage management experiences here include INTO THE WOODS, TARZAN, SHREK, LES MISERABLES, MISS SAIGON, FIDDLER ON THE ROOF, MY ONE AND ONLY, EVITA, ANYTHING GOES, WHITE CHRISTMAS, AIDA, SEVEN BRIDES FOR SEVEN BROTHERS, CRAZY FOR YOU, WILL ROGERS FOLLIES, GYPSY, OKLAHOMA, CHICAGO, DAMN YANKEES, BIG RIVER, ELEPHANT MAN, and PIPPIN. She was also proud to be the stage manager of the AACT award winning productions of SUNDAY IN THE PARK WITH GEORGE and SWEENEY TODD. Kristin graduated with a BS in psychology with honors from University of Florida and worked for several years as a social worker and case manager serving at-risk youth in Manatee County. Although Kristin has been involved with many other theatre companies, she considers MPAC to be her second home and is proud to be a part of the staff of such a wonderful company! “ Thank you to the many volunteer crew members, hard-working stage managers, and dedicated staff members who make coming to work a treat! ” Show more Show less EMAIL Ann Colonna Community Engagement Director Ann Colonna is a dedicated community leader and the Community Engagement Director for the Florida Cultural Group, a role she began in October 2024. With a passion for fostering connections and giving back, Ann brings extensive experience in community outreach, mentorship, and organizational leadership to the group’s mission. Originally from the Shenandoah Valley of Virginia, Ann attended High Point University in High Point, North Carolina, where she began developing her professional foundation. After a successful career in the staffing and sales industry, Ann transitioned to the nonprofit sector, seeking to make a more direct and lasting impact on her community. In addition to her role with the Florida Cultural Group, Ann is deeply involved in local mentorship through Take Stock in Children of Manatee County and Hillsborough County. She currently mentors three students and has successfully guided three others through graduation. Among her mentees, one has joined the U.S. Marine Corps, and two are pursuing their college education. Ann’s commitment to mentorship and her belief in the power of education have made a lasting impact on her students’ lives. Ann is also a graduate of Leadership Manatee and serves as the President of the Leadership Manatee Alumni Association, where she continues to promote leadership development and community engagement across the region. Her work with Leadership Manatee has solidified her as a key figure in shaping local leaders and fostering collaboration within the community. Outside of her professional and volunteer work, Ann enjoys traveling and spending time with her family and friends. Her enthusiasm for building relationships and empowering others. Show more Show less EMAIL Caren Brady Resident Costume Designer/Costume Shop Manager Caren Brady’s exemplary 37-year career in the theatre world reflects both her dedication and versatility in the realm of costume design. As the Resident Costume Designer and Costume Shop Manager at Manatee Performing Arts Center, which she joined in 2022, Caren brings a wealth of experience to every production she works on, a skillset honed through her extensive background in costume design, costume rental, and production management. A native of Ohio, Caren’s educational foundation was built at Bluffton College, where she earned her degree in theatre. Her career began at Stagecraft Theatrical in Cincinnati, where she not only worked in costume design but also expanded her role to owning and renaming the company to Cincinnati Costume Company. This entrepreneurial spirit set the stage for her later work with various production companies across the United States. Throughout her career, Caren has designed costumes for a wide range of productions, including plays, musicals, ballet, modern dance, television, and film. Among her favorite projects are My Fair Lady, Titanic, Gypsy, Something Rotten, and The Wizard of Oz—each of which demonstrates her ability to translate the artistic vision of a production into vibrant and fitting costume design. In addition to her professional accomplishments, Caren is a proud mother to her son Joe and his wife, Helena, and a dedicated pet parent to her mutt dog, Leon, rounding out a life that blends creativity with family. Her passion for theatre and costume design continues to inspire those around her, making her a key figure in the artistic communities she serves. Show more Show less EMAIL Isabella Onken Associate Isabella joined the Florida Cultural Group after graduating from Florida Gulf Coast University, where she dual-majored in Theatre and Communication. In May of 2023, she began an internship with Manatee Performing Arts Center, gaining invaluable hands-on experience that led to her official position on the staff in August 2023. She is thrilled to be in a role where she can apply her education while serving her local community. As part of the development team, Isabella is a facilitator to the organization and its patrons. She manages donations, sales, and funds with an eye on the future, working closely with staff and volunteers to help sustain the theatre’s growth. While her primary focus is on the longevity of the theatre and ensuring its continued success, Isabella uses her “jack-of-all-trades” enthusiasm to assist wherever possible. Whether it’s helping with day-to-day operations or supporting larger initiatives, she’s always ready to lend a hand. When Isabella isn’t in the office, she’s likely on stage. She made her debut with us in the highly successful Rocky Horror Show in 2023.  Behind the scenes, Isabella plays an active role in supporting productions, whether she’s selling tickets to the latest show or working with Ralph Nurmela to paint sets in the Kiwanis Blackbox Theatre. An accomplished writer, Isabella has been published multiple times for her poetry and is a dedicated participant in National Novel Writing Month (NaNoWriMo) every year. She is also a proud member of Our Ladies’ Rosary Makers at the national level and has been crafting rosaries since 2014. Isabella is incredibly proud of the opportunity to contribute to the artistic and cultural community and is excited to continue her journey of growth and service. Who knows where you’ll see her next, but she’ll be rallying support for Manatee Performing Arts Center every step of the way. The event is free and open to the public. At 8:15 a.m. there will be a Flag Raising and Taps at the Campus Entrance. At 8:30 a.m. the Remembrance Program will begin at the Campus Student Center Ballroom. Contact [email protected] or 941-359-4291 with questions. Please RSVP at 9-11 Remembrance Ceremony . more Add to Calendar SCF to host Sept. 11 ceremony 9:00am - 9:45am 11 SEP State College of Florida's Office of Veteran Services      and Student Veterans of America will host a memorial ceremony on Thursday,      September 11, 2025, from 9:00 a.m. to 9:45 a.m. at SCF Bradenton. The event will      take place near the flagpole at the south entrance. more Add to Calendar Annual Tribute to Heroes Memorial Ceremony 9:00am - 11:00am 11 SEP A Commemoration of Sept. 11 is taking place in Bradenton at Rossi Park, the site of the Manatee County Fire Chiefs' Association's annual Tribute to Heroes Memorial Ceremony. The ceremony will begin at 9 a.m. Sept. 11, 2025, at Rossi Park, 452 3rd Avenue West, Bradenton. It will be hosted by the Manatee County Fire      Chiefs' Association. more Add to Calendar Volunteers sought for Patriot Day at Sarasota National Cemetery 9:30am - 1:00pm 11 SEP In honor of 9/11, Patriot Day, there is a National Day of Service and Remembrance. Carry The Load is partnering with the National Cemetery Administration, Department of Veterans Affairs, to offer meaningful ways for Americans to honor those who have served our country. Volunteers at more than 60 VA National Cemeteries across the nation will help clean headstones and beautify the sacred grounds in tribute to our military, Veterans, first responders and their families. Sarasota National Cemetery, 9810 State Road 72, Sarasota, is participating in this day of service. The event begins at 9:30 a.m. and goes until 1 p.m. Thursday, Sept. 11, 2025.  Dress is casual and respectful. No open toe shoes or tank tops. The event will be outside. Please do not bring pets. Children are welcome but children younger than the age of 14 must be accompanied by an adult. You can register to volunteer at participate.carrytheload.org. more Add to Calendar Heroes Breakfast 8:00am - 10:00am 12 SEP ActivAge Sarasota is hosting a Heroes Breakfast with guest speakers from 8 a.m.-10 a.m. Sept.. 12, 2025. The event is at ActivAge Sarasota, 3801 Bee Ridge Road, Sarasota. Guest speaker will be Rob Kehs, a U.S. Navy Veteran and President of SRQ Vets. Kehs will share the mission of SRQ Vets, a non-profit organization, and the many ways they provide comprehensive support to our local Veterans. The honored Veteran of the Month will be announced. All Veterans are welcome to attend and enjoy a free breakfast. Call 941-269-2273 to RSVP. more Add to Calendar Commissioners The Board of County Commissioners, together with Manatee County's five constitutional officers, comprise Manatee County Government. The Board of County Commission establishes policy for County departments and appoints the County Administrator who carries out the day-to-day business of the County. For more information about the Board of County Commissioners, visit their page . To view the upcoming agendas, visit Agenda Online.
